p.s: In his speech, given at the COP26 World Leader's Summit Opening Ceremony on 1 November 2021, the British Prime Minister Boris Johnson convinces his audience of their responsibility of taking action against climate change and draws a fighting picture of its dangers by structuring and embellishing his arguments and by using specific stylistic devices like repetitions and comparatives.
His speech is divided into 8 paragraphs.
After welcoming the audience and referingreferring to the occasion of his speech Boris Johnson introduces the topic by drawing a comparison between James Bond movies and climate change see l. 2-6).
He expresses through this comparison that we are in the same position as the humans in the movies who fear a doomsday device.
Especially the description of a red digital clock (l. 4 f.) symbolises that we have been waiting for too long to take action.
His allusion stresses directly at the beginning of his speech the danger of the climate crisis.
The Prime Minister also makes us humans responsible for this.
The secoundsecond paragraph deals with other agreements towards climate crisis like the Paris agreement (see l. 11) and their failure.
Through this reference Boris Johnson proves the necessity of the COP26.
In hte following paragraphs the Prime Minister explains exactly why and how the COP26 should take action.
He explains the financial problem because of the industrialized countries which ignore the problem and they chance to help other countries through financial support.
Even though this was promised at the Paris agreement the money will not deliver.
Boris Johnson gives a solution in the next paragraph.
He stresses out that if all countries work together, we would have enough money to make progresses.
By using the example of how the private sector money helped the UK to end their dependence on coal, the author embellishsembellishes his argument (see l. 27f.).
After his argumentation of the way the COP26 could change things, the Prime Minister highlights why they should do that.
He visualizevisualizes the responsibility towards the audience of posterity (l. 39) and that they will not forgive them their failure.
Boris Johnson uses facts like half of the population of the world [are] under 30 (l. 35) to prove his point.
At the end he sums up that they have all things they need to take action.
He concludes his speech by referring back to his allusion of James Bond in the beginning of his speech and appeals to his aufience.
He gives them hope and encourage them to take action.
Furthermore Boris Johnson convinces his audience by using rhetorical devices.
Through his inclusive language (see l. 16) and phrases like We in this room (l. 22) he appeals to the audience and the moral of the members of COP26.
The Repetionrepetition of the words we can (l. 16, 30, and 53) draws a frame through his argumentation and indicates hope.
Addiotnally ellipses and parataxes, which can be find in line 23 No question or in line 46 following allude that doing something can be simple.
The author ilustratesillustrates the neessity of taking action through the comparative in line 30.
All together Boris Johnson convinces the audience by drawing a dangerous picture of climate change and encourage the audience to take action.
This intention works out because of the structure of his argumentation and the use of rhetorical devices.
